title: RS22623
content: The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement, survivors, disability, unemployment, and sickness benefits for railroad workers and their families. Workers covered by the RRB system include those employed by railroads engaged in interstate commerce. The RRB system is separate from Social Security but closely coordinated. To qualify for an RRB annuity, a worker generally needs at least 10 years of covered railroad work. Family members of insured railroad workers receive RRB annuities equal to or greater than Social Security benefits. If a worker doesn't qualify for an RRB annuity, their railroad work counts toward Social Security benefits. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement benefits for railroad workers and their families. RRB annuities consist of tier I and tier II components, with tier I amounts equivalent to Social Security benefits and tier II amounts paid in addition to tier I. Surviving spouses may be eligible for widow or widower annuities from RRB. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement benefits for railroad workers and their families. RRB survivor annuities are generally higher than comparable Social Security benefits due to tier II amounts. Surviving spouses may receive up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity at full retirement age. Widow(er)s caring for a deceased worker's child under 16 may receive an annuity of up to 75% of tier I amount plus 100% of tier II amount. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widow(er)s. The 2001 law (P.L. 107-90) increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widow(er)s. Other provisions in the law include changes to widow(er)'s annuities, such as allowing investments in non-governmental assets, removing early retirement reduction for employees with 30 years of experience, reducing vesting years for tier II annuities, repealing maximum limitation on annuities, and phasing in changes to the tier II tax structure. These changes apply to widow(er)s receiving annuities from February 2002 onwards, with some retroactive benefits for those who would have received higher benefits under the new rules. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widow(er)s by adding a new guaranty amount. This new law raised the total initial minimum amount to 100% of the tier I and tier II amounts the employee would have received at the time the widow(er) begins to receive an annuity. The components of a widow(er)'s regular annuity change over time, with both the tier I and regular tier II amounts increasing each year. The widow(er)'s monthly annuity remains the same in nominal terms but declines in real terms due to inflation. Once the guaranty amount is reduced to zero, the widow(er) will start receiving an increase in their total monthly annuity. All eligible widow(er)s receive annuities greater than or equal to what they would have received under prior law. The tier I and regular tier II annuities increase annually with the applicable COLA. Widow(er)s eligible for the initial minimum amount from the 2001 law receive annuities greater than under prior law. In 2005, the average aged widow(er) annuity was $1,416 per month, up from $1,138 in 2001. A widow under current law in 2006 would receive an initial minimum amount of $1,300 per month, compared to $1,150 under prior law. The widow's total annuity amount is $1,300 per month under current law, consisting of $1,000 from tier I and $300 from tier II. Her annuity does not increase due to COLAs until her tier I and regular tier II amounts exceed the initial minimum amount. The components of her annuity change annually, with tier I increasing by $23 and regular tier II increasing by $1 each year. The guaranty amount decreases by $24 annually. The guaranty amount decreases each year after 2006 as tier I and tier II amounts increase.
